Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery little-master cup; interior: rim glazed black; dilute lines on wall; exterior: on rim, myrtle leaf pattern; handle zone reserved with band at top; glazed below; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as belonging to a Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim, the decorative motif and carinated junction of the rim and body find parallels with his South Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9C. Type 9C cups correspond to Attic Siana, Band, and Gordion cups and find parallels with Hayes Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). These cups have been found in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Bibliographic references: Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 66, no. 815, pl. XXI, no. 815)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 688, no. 464)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 52, no. 294)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.771) (Phase 3)
